0.text: One of the strangest things about relationships is that we're not free to feel attracted to just anyone.

6.text: We tend to have very strong psychological types that we can't deviate from.

11.text: All of us carry inside us very specific inner shopping lists, defining what the people we can love need to be like as characters.

19.text: You might think these shopping lists would be focused around lovely requirements.

23.text: Like that our potential lovers would need to be kind, understanding, friendly and from our age and social group.

29.text: But the shopping lists are in fact often a lot wierder and darker.

34.text: We may end up neglecting all sorts of potential candidates, dismissing them as boring or yucky or somehow just wrong

41.text: and heading straight to people whose characteristics are pretty akward and not conducive to our happiness.

47.text: For example, we may only be able to fall in love with people who are much less clever or responsible than we are.

53.text: Or who are really unreliable, who are selfish and self-absorbed, or sarcastic and mean.

59.text: It can be very puzzling to those around us and to ourselves.

62.text: Why on earth can't we settle down with people who are good for us?

66.text: That's because what we're looking for in love isn't necessarily someone who is nice, pure and simple

74.text: And a lot of us learned about love in childhood, at the hands of people who were, in a variety of ways, trouble for us

82.text: and who continue unconsciously to guide our love types.

86.text: Our earliest caregivers give us templates of what it is to love and be loved

91.text: which can cause havoc with our chances of happiness.

94.text: The trickiness in our love types tend to go in one of three ways.

98.text: Let's imagine dad was cold or violent or abusive, or mom was belittling, unavailable or controlling.

105.text: It was horrible, yet that ends up being what we look for in love.

109.text: Why would we ever repeat something that was deeply uncomfortable?

112.text: Well, because even though it was horrible, it was still a love relationship.

116.text: There was abuse but also, let's imagine, a degree of familiarity, admiration, attachment and even tenderness.

124.text: They may have been belittling, but it's what we got used to.

127.text: And now, however illogical it sounds, it doesn't quite feel right unless it's kind of awful as well.

133.text: It's not nice as such, but it feels comfortingly, compellingly familiar.

139.text: Or, imagine the experience firsthand... what it was like to be made to feel terrible, to be humiliated and hurt.

146.text: And then, wierdly, we may end up doing the same thing to someone else.

150.text: Humiliating them in turn, bossing them about, going cold on them just when they're vulnerable to us.

156.text: It's as if a primitive part of us thinks that the only way not to be abused is to be the abuser.

162.text: Deep inside the child-like emotional self thinks the person who did that thing to me was, in a way, the opposite of me,

170.text: and that must be the place of safety, and that's who I want to be in any relationship.

177.text: When parents cause us trouble, we're often so keen to get away from it, we develop blocks around all kind of character traits they may have had

184.text: which might actually have been good and actually unrelated to the troublesome traits.

189.text: So, for example, our father might have been belittling but highly intelligent.

193.text: Now, regrettably, anyone intelligent can be seen hugely putting us off.

197.text: Or we always felt our mother was somehow revolted by sexuality, ours especially, but she was really warm and cuddly.

204.text: Now, sadly, anyone who is warm and cuddly is imagined to be punitive around sex

209.text: and hence feels wrong and has to be rejected.

212.text: Our inner love maps are really hard to tease out.

215.text: They certainly don't spell themselves out, so we have to make efforts to find out what they're dictating

220.text: so as to free ourselves from their demands.

223.text: The investigation starts, as always, by trying to understand ourselves.

227.text: What did I suffer from at the hands of my early caregivers?

230.text: Am I finding myself drawn to that in adults I fancy?

234.text: Am I causing trouble for people in ways I might have suffered from when I was young?

239.text: Am I putting off certain people because they have traits I associate with people who cause me difficulties as a child?

245.text: Might I in other people find the traits I like without the ones I fear?

251.text: Emotional health means expanding on the number of people we're free to fall in love with.

256.text: We learn about love in childhood,

258.text: but we liberate ourselves from the traumas of childhood when we realize we can love in different ways,

263.text: and get used to something that may at first be eerily and challengingly unfamiliar.

269.text: Being happy with someone who is properly and deeply good for us.
